complete_sentence: Domani sera ceniamo insieme al ristorante in centro.
question_text: Domani sera ___ insieme al ristorante in centro.
english_translation: Tomorrow evening we are having dinner together at the restaurant downtown.
explanation: The present tense 'ceniamo' expresses a planned future action (we are having dinner).

complete_sentence: Quando ero bambino, giocavo sempre con i miei amici in giardino.
question_text: Quando ___ bambino, giocavo sempre con i miei amici in giardino.
english_translation: When I was a child, I always played with my friends in the garden.
explanation: The imperfetto 'ero' is used to describe a continuous state in the past.

complete_sentence: Ieri sera ho scritto un'email al mio professore.
question_text: Ieri sera ho ___ un'email al mio professore.
english_translation: Last night I wrote an email to my professor.
explanation: The verb 'scrivere' (to write) has an irregular past participle: 'scritto'. The 'passato prossimo' is formed with the auxiliary verb 'avere' followed by the past participle.

complete_sentence: Sono molto contenta perché ho passato l'esame di storia.
question_text: Sono molto contenta perché ho passato l'___ di storia.
english_translation: I am very happy because I passed the history exam.
explanation: This question tests vocabulary for academic life. 'Esame' is the Italian word for 'exam'. 'Lezione' is a lesson, 'materia' is a subject, and 'aula' is a classroom.

complete_sentence: Quanti fratelli hai? Ne ho due.
question_text: Quanti fratelli hai? ___ ho due.
english_translation: How many brothers do you have? I have two (of them).
explanation: The partitive pronoun 'ne' means 'of them' or 'of it' and is used to replace a noun that is preceded by an expression of quantity (like 'due'). Here, 'ne' replaces 'di fratelli' (of brothers).

complete_sentence: Questa maglietta è troppo piccola. Avete una taglia più grande?
question_text: Questa maglietta è troppo piccola. Avete una ___ più grande?
english_translation: This t-shirt is too small. Do you have a bigger size?
explanation: This question tests shopping vocabulary. 'Taglia' is the correct word for clothing 'size'. 'Numero' is used for shoe size, 'prezzo' is price, and 'colore' is color.

complete_sentence: Sbrigati, il treno sta per partire!
question_text: Sbrigati, il treno ___ partire!
english_translation: Hurry up, the train is about to leave!
explanation: The construction 'stare per + infinito' is used to express an action that is about to happen imminently. The verb 'stare' is conjugated to agree with the subject ('il treno' is third-person singular, so 'sta').

complete_sentence: Buongiorno, vorrei del pane e un litro di latte.
question_text: Buongiorno, vorrei ___ pane e un litro di latte.
english_translation: Good morning, I would like some bread and a liter of milk.
explanation: The partitive article 'del' (di + il) is used to indicate an unspecified quantity of an uncountable noun like 'pane' (bread). It translates to 'some' in English.

complete_sentence: Stamattina ho preso il treno delle otto per andare al lavoro.
question_text: Stamattina ho ___ il treno delle otto per andare al lavoro.
english_translation: This morning I took the eight o'clock train to go to work.
explanation: The verb 'prendere' (to take) has an irregular past participle, which is 'preso'. The 'passato prossimo' is formed with the auxiliary verb 'avere' followed by the past participle.

complete_sentence: Hai visto il film di cui ti ho parlato?
question_text: Hai ___ il film di cui ti ho parlato?
english_translation: Have you seen the movie I told you about?
explanation: The verb 'vedere' (to see) has an irregular past participle, 'visto'. Although 'veduto' exists, 'visto' is far more common in modern Italian.

complete_sentence: Mio nonno è un uomo molto saggio e mi dà sempre buoni consigli.
question_text: Mio nonno è un uomo molto ___ e mi dà sempre buoni consigli.
english_translation: My grandfather is a very wise man and always gives me good advice.
explanation: Adjectives must agree in gender and number with the noun they modify. 'Uomo' (man) is a masculine singular noun, so the adjective must be in the masculine singular form, 'saggio'.

complete_sentence: Le mie amiche sono arrivate ieri sera da Milano.
question_text: Le mie amiche sono ___ ieri sera da Milano.
english_translation: My (female) friends arrived last night from Milan.
explanation: The verb 'arrivare' uses the auxiliary 'essere' in the 'passato prossimo'. When 'essere' is used, the past participle must agree in gender and number with the subject. 'Le mie amiche' is feminine plural, so the correct form is 'arrivate'.

complete_sentence: Stasera non posso uscire perché ho molto da studiare.
question_text: Stasera non posso ___ perché ho molto da studiare.
english_translation: Tonight I can't go out because I have a lot to study.
explanation: Modal verbs like 'potere' (can), 'dovere' (must), and 'volere' (want) are followed by the infinitive form of the main verb. After the conjugated modal 'posso', the main verb must be in its infinitive form, 'uscire'.

complete_sentence: Per questa ricetta serve del pane grattugiato.
question_text: Per questa ricetta serve ___ pane grattugiato.
english_translation: For this recipe, you need some breadcrumbs.
explanation: The partitive article 'del' ('di' + 'il') is used to express an indefinite quantity ('some') of an uncountable noun ('pane'). 'Il' would mean 'the breadcrumbs' (a specific batch), and 'un' is for countable nouns.

complete_sentence: Ho visto dei bei quadri alla mostra d'arte.
question_text: Ho visto ___ bei quadri alla mostra d'arte.
english_translation: I saw some beautiful paintings at the art exhibition.
explanation: To express an unspecified quantity of a plural noun ('quadri'), the partitive article is used. 'Dei' ('di' + 'i') means 'some' and is the plural equivalent of the indefinite article 'un'.

complete_sentence: Da piccolo, giocavo sempre in giardino con mio fratello.
question_text: Da piccolo, ___ sempre in giardino con mio fratello.
english_translation: When I was little, I used to play in the garden with my brother.
explanation: The imperfect tense ('imperfetto'), 'giocavo', is used to describe habitual or repeated actions in the past. The phrase 'Da piccolo' (When I was little) signals the need for this tense.

complete_sentence: Stamattina mi sono vestita in fretta.
question_text: Stamattina mi sono ___ in fretta.
english_translation: This morning I got dressed quickly.
explanation: Reflexive verbs like 'vestirsi' always use the auxiliary 'essere' in the 'passato prossimo'. The past participle must agree with the subject. The hint indicates the speaker is feminine singular, so the correct form is 'vestita'.

complete_sentence: Era una bella giornata e il sole splendeva.
question_text: ___ una bella giornata e il sole splendeva.
english_translation: It was a beautiful day and the sun was shining.
explanation: The imperfect tense 'era' is used to describe states, conditions (like weather), and to set the scene in the past. It describes an ongoing situation rather than a completed action.

complete_sentence: Scusi, ci porta il conto, per favore?
question_text: Scusi, ci porta il ___, per favore?
english_translation: Excuse me, could you bring us the bill, please?
explanation: In a restaurant context, 'il conto' is the correct term for 'the bill' or 'the check'.

complete_sentence: Vai spesso al mare? Sì, ci vado ogni fine settimana.
question_text: Vai spesso al mare? Sì, ___ vado ogni fine settimana.
english_translation: Do you go to the sea often? Yes, I go there every weekend.
explanation: The particle 'ci' is used to replace a previously mentioned place, meaning 'there'. In this sentence, 'ci' replaces 'al mare' (to the sea). It is placed before the conjugated verb.

complete_sentence: Puoi aiutarmi, per favore?
question_text: ___ aiutarmi, per favore?
english_translation: Can you help me, please?
explanation: The modal verb 'potere' (to be able to/can) is followed by an infinitive. To make a polite request using the informal 'tu', the correct conjugation is 'puoi'.

complete_sentence: Domani ho un esame difficile.
question_text: Domani ho un ___ difficile.
english_translation: Tomorrow I have a difficult exam.
explanation: In an academic context, the word for a test or exam is 'esame'. 'Lezione' is a lesson/lecture, and 'compito' is homework.

complete_sentence: Il nostro appartamento ha tre camere da letto e due bagni.
question_text: Il nostro appartamento ha tre camere da letto e due ___.
english_translation: Our apartment has three bedrooms and two bathrooms.
explanation: After 'due' (two), nouns must be plural. 'Bagni' is the plural form of 'bagno' (bathroom).

complete_sentence: Questo libro costa duemila euro.
question_text: Questo libro costa ___ euro.
english_translation: This book costs two thousand euros.
explanation: Numbers in the thousands are written as one word: 'duemila' (2000), 'tremila' (3000), etc.

complete_sentence: La popolazione di questa città è di cinquecentomila abitanti.
question_text: La popolazione di questa città è di ___ abitanti.
english_translation: The population of this city is five hundred thousand inhabitants.
explanation: Large compound numbers are written as one word. 'Cinquecentomila' means 500,000.

complete_sentence: Vorrei ordinare il pesce del giorno, per favore.
question_text: Vorrei ___ il pesce del giorno, per favore.
english_translation: I would like to order the fish of the day, please.
explanation: After 'vorrei' (I would like), use the infinitive form of the verb. 'Ordinare' means 'to order'.

complete_sentence: A Maria è piaciuta molto la pizza ieri sera.
question_text: A Maria è ___ molto la pizza ieri sera.
english_translation: Maria really liked the pizza last night.
explanation: With 'piacere' in the passato prossimo, the past participle agrees with the subject. 'Pizza' is feminine, so 'piaciuta'.

complete_sentence: Ho comprato questo libro per centouno euro.
question_text: Ho comprato questo libro per ___ euro.
english_translation: I bought this book for one hundred and one euros.
explanation: In Italian, 'cento' and 'uno' are combined to form a single word 'centouno'. The conjunction 'e' (and) is not used between them.

complete_sentence: Il volo per Roma costa duecentottanta euro.
question_text: Il volo per Roma costa ___ euro.
english_translation: The flight to Rome costs two hundred and eighty euros.
explanation: When a number ending in a vowel (like 'duecento') precedes a number starting with a vowel ('ottanta'), the first vowel is dropped and the words are joined: 'duecentottanta'.

complete_sentence: La stanza numero centoventitré è al secondo piano.
question_text: La stanza numero ___ è al secondo piano.
english_translation: Room number one hundred and twenty-three is on the second floor.
explanation: Cardinal numbers in Italian are written as a single word. Numbers ending in 'tre' (three) must have an acute accent on the final 'e' ('tré') to mark the stress.

complete_sentence: Questa città è stata fondata nel duemila avanti Cristo.
question_text: Questa città è stata fondata nel ___ avanti Cristo.
english_translation: This city was founded in two thousand BC.
explanation: For multiples of one thousand, the singular form 'mille' changes to 'mila' and is attached to the preceding number to form a single word, such as 'duemila', 'tremila', etc.

complete_sentence: Mio fratello è nato nel millenovecentonovantacinque.
question_text: Mio fratello è nato nel ___.
english_translation: My brother was born in 1995.
explanation: Large numbers, including years, are written as a single, continuous word in Italian without any spaces or conjunctions.

complete_sentence: Ci sono circa trecento studenti in questa scuola.
question_text: Ci sono circa ___ studenti in questa scuola.
english_translation: There are about three hundred students in this school.
explanation: To form multiples of one hundred, the digit (e.g., 'tre') is combined with 'cento' to make a single word ('trecento'). The word 'cento' is invariable and does not become 'centi' in this context.

complete_sentence: Il libro ha quattrocentoquarantuno pagine.
question_text: Il libro ha ___ pagine.
english_translation: The book has four hundred and forty-one pages.
explanation: When a number ending in a consonant (like the 'a' in 'quaranta') is followed by 'uno', they are combined into a single word. No vowel is dropped in this case.

complete_sentence: L'affitto mensile per questo appartamento è di cinquecentosessantasette euro.
question_text: L'affitto mensile per questo appartamento è di ___ euro.
english_translation: The monthly rent for this apartment is five hundred and sixty-seven euros.
explanation: In Italian, complex cardinal numbers are written as a single, long word by joining all the component numbers without spaces.

complete_sentence: Questo libro ha trecento pagine.
question_text: Questo libro ha ___ pagine.
english_translation: This book has three hundred pages.
explanation: The number 'cento' (hundred) is invariable in Italian, meaning it does not change its ending to agree with the gender or number of the noun it modifies. It is always 'cento'.

complete_sentence: Ho pagato centocinquanta euro per queste scarpe.
question_text: Ho pagato ___ euro per queste scarpe.
english_translation: I paid one hundred and fifty euros for these shoes.
explanation: When 'cento' is followed by another number, it forms a single word without the conjunction 'e'. For example, 101 is 'centouno', and 150 is 'centocinquanta'.

complete_sentence: In questo piccolo paese vivono circa mille persone.
question_text: In questo piccolo paese vivono circa ___ persone.
english_translation: About a thousand people live in this small town.
explanation: The number for 'one thousand' is 'mille'. The plural form, 'mila', is used for numbers from two thousand upwards (e.g., duemila, tremila).

complete_sentence: La mia macchina è costata ventimila euro.
question_text: La mia macchina è costata ___ euro.
english_translation: My car cost twenty thousand euros.
explanation: For numbers greater than one thousand, the plural form 'mila' is used. It is joined to the preceding number to form a single word, like 'duemila' (2,000) or 'ventimila' (20,000).

complete_sentence: Mio nonno è nato nel millenovecentosettantotto.
question_text: Mio nonno è nato nel ___.
english_translation: My grandfather was born in nineteen seventy-eight (1978).
explanation: Years are written as a single, compound number in Italian. 'Millenovecento' (1900) is one word. When a number ending in a vowel (like 'settanta') is followed by 'otto', the final vowel is dropped, creating 'settantotto'.

complete_sentence: In questo hotel ci sono duecentouno stanze.
question_text: In questo hotel ci sono ___ stanze.
english_translation: There are two hundred and one rooms in this hotel.
explanation: The number 'uno' does not change to 'una' before a feminine noun when it is part of a larger compound number. 'Cento' is invariable, and 'uno' is attached directly to it, forming 'duecentouno'.

complete_sentence: L'azienda ha cinquemilacinquecento dipendenti.
question_text: L'azienda ha ___ dipendenti.
english_translation: The company has five thousand five hundred employees.
explanation: Large numbers in Italian are often written as one single word. 'Cinquemila' (5,000) and 'cinquecento' (500) combine to form 'cinquemilacinquecento'.

complete_sentence: Questa bicicletta costa quattrocentottantuno euro.
question_text: Questa bicicletta costa ___ euro.
english_translation: This bicycle costs four hundred and eighty-one euros.
explanation: When a number ending in a vowel (like 'ottanta') is followed by 'uno' or 'otto', the final vowel is dropped (elision), forming 'ottantuno'. This is then attached to 'quattrocento' to make the single word 'quattrocentottantuno'.

complete_sentence: In questa biblioteca ci sono centouno libri antichi.
question_text: In questa biblioteca ci sono ___ libri antichi.
english_translation: In this library, there are one hundred and one ancient books.
explanation: Numbers that include 'uno' (one) at the end, like 101, 201, etc., are written as a single word. So, 'cento' and 'uno' combine to become 'centouno'. The form 'centun' is used only before a singular masculine noun (e.g., 'centun libro').

complete_sentence: Ho speso duecento euro per la spesa questa settimana.
question_text: Ho speso ___ euro per la spesa questa settimana.
english_translation: I spent two hundred euros on groceries this week.
explanation: The number 'cento' (hundred) is invariable, meaning it does not change its ending to agree in gender or number with the noun it modifies. It is always 'cento', never 'centi'.

complete_sentence: Mio nonno ha compiuto ottantotto anni la settimana scorsa.
question_text: Mio nonno ha compiuto ___ anni la settimana scorsa.
english_translation: My grandfather turned eighty-eight last week.
explanation: When a number ending in a vowel (like 'ottanta') is followed by a number beginning with a vowel (like 'otto' or 'uno'), the final vowel of the first number is dropped and the two are written as one word without an apostrophe. 'Ottanta' + 'otto' becomes 'ottantotto'.

complete_sentence: Questa città ha più di mille abitanti.
question_text: Questa città ha più di ___ abitanti.
english_translation: This city has more than one thousand inhabitants.
explanation: The number for 'one thousand' is simply 'mille'. Unlike other numbers, it does not use 'uno' or 'un' before it. The plural form, used from 2000 onwards, is 'mila' (e.g., 'duemila').

complete_sentence: L'azienda ha venduto duemila automobili quest'anno.
question_text: L'azienda ha venduto ___ automobili quest'anno.
english_translation: The company sold two thousand cars this year.
explanation: The plural of 'mille' (thousand) is 'mila'. It combines with the preceding number to form a single word. Therefore, 'due' + 'mila' becomes 'duemila'.

complete_sentence: Il biglietto del concerto costa trecentocinquanta euro.
question_text: Il biglietto del concerto costa ___ euro.
english_translation: The concert ticket costs three hundred and fifty euros.
explanation: In Italian, compound numbers are generally written as a single, continuous word without spaces or conjunctions. Thus, 'trecento' (three hundred) and 'cinquanta' (fifty) combine to form 'trecentocinquanta'.

complete_sentence: Cristoforo Colombo è arrivato in America nel millequattrocentonovantadue.
question_text: Cristoforo Colombo è arrivato in America nel ___.
english_translation: Christopher Columbus arrived in America in fourteen ninety-two (1492).
explanation: Years, like other large compound numbers, are written as a single word in Italian. 'Mille' + 'quattrocento' + 'novantadue' are joined together to become 'millequattrocentonovantadue'.

complete_sentence: In Italia ci sono circa sessanta milioni di abitanti.
question_text: In Italia ci sono circa sessanta ___ di abitanti.
english_translation: In Italy, there are about sixty million inhabitants.
explanation: Unlike 'cento' and 'mille', 'milione' (million) is a noun. It has a singular form ('milione' for one million) and a plural form ('milioni' for two or more million). Since the number is sixty, the plural form is required. It is also followed by 'di'.

complete_sentence: Luca è un ragazzo basso con i capelli castani.
question_text: Luca è un ragazzo ___ con i capelli castani.
english_translation: Luca is a short boy with brown hair.
explanation: Adjectives must agree with the noun's gender and number. 'Ragazzo' is masculine singular, so 'basso' is correct.

complete_sentence: Di gelato? Sì, ne prendo un po'.
question_text: Di gelato? Sì, ___ prendo un po'.
english_translation: Some ice cream? Yes, I'll take some of it.
explanation: The particle 'ne' replaces 'di + noun' to mean 'some of it' or 'of it/them'.

complete_sentence: La pizza non mi è piaciuta per niente.
question_text: La pizza non mi è ___ per niente.
english_translation: I didn't like the pizza at all.
explanation: With piacere in passato prossimo, the past participle agrees with the subject. 'Pizza' is feminine singular, so 'piaciuta'.

complete_sentence: Non sto bene, ho mal di testa da ieri.
question_text: Non sto bene, ho mal di ___ da ieri.
english_translation: I don't feel well, I've had a headache since yesterday.
explanation: 'Mal di testa' (headache) uses the feminine singular noun 'testa' (head).

complete_sentence: Il concerto ha avuto un pubblico di ottantamila persone.
question_text: Il concerto ha avuto un pubblico di ___ persone.
english_translation: The concert had an audience of eighty thousand people.
explanation: Large numbers are written as compound words. 'Ottantamila' means 80,000.

complete_sentence: Ho risparmiato trecentocinquanta euro questo mese.
question_text: Ho risparmiato ___ euro questo mese.
english_translation: I saved three hundred fifty euros this month.
explanation: Compound numbers in Italian are written as one word. 'Trecentocinquanta' means 350.

complete_sentence: La casa dei miei nonni vale seicentomila euro.
question_text: La casa dei miei nonni vale ___ euro.
english_translation: My grandparents' house is worth six hundred thousand euros.
explanation: Numbers with hundreds of thousands are written as one word. 'Seicentomila' means 600,000.

complete_sentence: Nel negozio c'erano duecento clienti oggi.
question_text: Nel negozio c'erano ___ clienti oggi.
english_translation: There were two hundred customers in the store today.
explanation: Numbers in the hundreds are written as one word. 'Duecento' means 200 and doesn't change form.

complete_sentence: La distanza tra le due città è di centoventi chilometri.
question_text: La distanza tra le due città è di ___ chilometri.
english_translation: The distance between the two cities is one hundred twenty kilometers.
explanation: Numbers combining hundreds and tens are written as one word. 'Centoventi' means 120.

complete_sentence: L'università ha novecento studenti quest'anno.
question_text: L'università ha ___ studenti quest'anno.
english_translation: The university has nine hundred students this year.
explanation: Numbers in the hundreds are written as one word and are invariable. 'Novecento' means 900.

complete_sentence: Ieri, io sono andato al cinema
question_text: Ieri, io ___ al cinema
english_translation: Yesterday, I went to the cinema.
explanation: RULE: The 'passato prossimo' is used for completed actions in the past. As a verb of motion, 'andare' uses the auxiliary verb 'essere'. The past participle must agree with the subject, so for a male speaker ('io'), the correct form is 'sono andato'.

complete_sentence: Maria ha scritto una lettera ieri.
question_text: Maria ___ una lettera ieri. (scrivere)
english_translation: Maria wrote a letter yesterday.
explanation: RULE: The 'passato prossimo' is used for completed past actions. The verb 'scrivere' is transitive and uses the auxiliary verb 'avere'. Its past participle is irregular: 'scritto'. For 'Maria' (lei), the form is 'ha scritto'.

complete_sentence: Noi eravamo stanchi dopo il viaggio
question_text: Noi ___ stanchi dopo il viaggio
english_translation: We were tired after the trip.
explanation: RULE: The 'imperfetto' is used to describe states of being or conditions in the past. For the verb 'essere', the first-person plural ('noi') form in the imperfetto is 'eravamo'.

complete_sentence: Mentre preparavo la cena, la radio suonava
question_text: Mentre ___ la cena, la radio suonava
english_translation: While I was preparing dinner, the radio was playing.
explanation: RULE: The 'imperfetto' is used to describe an ongoing action in the past that serves as a background for another event. The 'io' form of 'preparare' in the imperfetto is 'preparavo'.

complete_sentence: Domani andremo al mare
question_text: Domani ___ al mare
english_translation: Tomorrow we will go to the beach.
explanation: RULE: 'Futuro semplice' is used to express future actions. The future tense of the irregular verb 'andare' for the 'noi' (we) form is 'andremo'.

complete_sentence: Se avessi tempo, andrei in palestra
question_text: Se avessi tempo, ___ in palestra
english_translation: If I had time, I would go to the gym.
explanation: RULE: The 'condizionale' is used to express a hypothetical action. The first-person singular ('io') conditional form of 'andare' is 'andrei'.

complete_sentence: Io posso parlare tre lingue.
question_text: Io ___ parlare tre lingue. (potere)
english_translation: I can speak three languages.
explanation: RULE: The modal verb 'potere' expresses ability or possibility. The first-person singular ('io') present tense form is 'posso'.

complete_sentence: Lei deve studiare per l'esame.
question_text: Lei ___ studiare per l'esame. (dovere)
english_translation: She has to study for the exam.
explanation: RULE: The modal verb 'dovere' expresses necessity or obligation. The third-person singular ('lei') present tense form is 'deve'.

complete_sentence: Tu vuoi venire con noi?
question_text: Tu ___ venire con noi? (volere)
english_translation: Do you want to come with us?
explanation: RULE: The modal verb 'volere' expresses a desire or wish. The second-person singular ('tu') present tense form is 'vuoi'.

complete_sentence: Noi dobbiamo finire questo lavoro oggi.
question_text: Noi ___ finire questo lavoro oggi. (dovere)
english_translation: We have to finish this work today.
explanation: RULE: The modal verb 'dovere' expresses necessity or obligation. The first-person plural ('noi') present tense form is 'dobbiamo'.

complete_sentence: Loro sanno suonare il piano.
question_text: Loro ___ suonare il piano. (sapere)
english_translation: They know how to play the piano.
explanation: RULE: The modal verb 'sapere' is used to express a learned skill or knowledge. The third-person plural ('loro') present tense form is 'sanno'.

complete_sentence: Io non so guidare.
question_text: Io non ___ guidare. (sapere)
english_translation: I don't know how to drive.
explanation: RULE: The modal verb 'sapere' is used to express an ability or skill. The first-person singular ('io') present tense form is 'so'.

complete_sentence: Voi potete aiutarmi?
question_text: Voi ___ aiutarmi? (potere)
english_translation: Can you help me?
explanation: RULE: The modal verb 'potere' is used for requests and to express ability. The second-person plural ('voi') present tense form is 'potete'.

complete_sentence: Lei ha dormito tutta la notte.
question_text: Lei ha ___ tutta la notte. (dormire)
english_translation: She slept all night.
explanation: RULE: The 'passato prossimo' of 'dormire' is formed with the auxiliary verb 'avere'. The past participle of 'dormire' is 'dormito'.

complete_sentence: Noi siamo alzati presto stamattina
question_text: Noi siamo ___ presto stamattina
english_translation: We got up early this morning.
explanation: RULE: Reflexive verbs, like 'alzarsi', always use the auxiliary verb 'essere' in the 'passato prossimo'. The past participle must agree in gender and number with the subject ('noi' - plural), becoming 'alzati'.

complete_sentence: Tu hai ricevuto un bel regalo.
question_text: Tu hai ___ un bel regalo. (ricevere)
english_translation: You received a nice gift.
explanation: RULE: The verb 'ricevere' uses the auxiliary 'avere' in the 'passato prossimo'. The past participle for regular -ere verbs is formed by changing the ending to '-uto', resulting in 'ricevuto'.

complete_sentence: Io ho risposto al telefono.
question_text: Io ho ___ al telefono. (rispondere)
english_translation: I answered the phone.
explanation: RULE: The verb 'rispondere' uses the auxiliary 'avere' in the 'passato prossimo'. It has an irregular past participle, which is 'risposto'.

complete_sentence: Loro sono partiti in treno.
question_text: Loro sono ___ in treno. (partire)
english_translation: They left by train.
explanation: RULE: 'Partire' is a verb of motion that uses the auxiliary verb 'essere' in the 'passato prossimo'. The past participle must agree with the plural subject ('loro'), becoming 'partiti'.

complete_sentence: Quando ero bambino, giocavo sempre calcio.
question_text: Quando ero bambino, ___ sempre calcio. (giocare)
english_translation: When I was a child, I always played soccer.
explanation: RULE: The 'imperfetto' is used to describe habitual or repeated actions in the past. The first-person singular ('io') form of 'giocare' in the imperfetto is 'giocavo'.

complete_sentence: Ieri sera ho guardato la televisione.
question_text: Ieri sera ___ la televisione. (guardare)
english_translation: Last night I watched television.
explanation: RULE: The 'passato prossimo' is used for a specific, completed action in the past ('ieri sera'). 'Guardare' uses the auxiliary 'avere', so the correct form is 'ho guardato'.

complete_sentence: Maria era molto bella da piccola.
question_text: Maria ___ molto bella da piccola. (essere)
english_translation: Maria was very beautiful as a child.
explanation: RULE: The 'imperfetto' is used for descriptions in the past. The third-person singular ('lei') form of 'essere' in the imperfetto is 'era'.

complete_sentence: La settimana scorsa ho visitato mia nonna.
question_text: La settimana scorsa ___ mia nonna. (visitare)
english_translation: Last week I visited my grandmother.
explanation: RULE: The 'passato prossimo' is used for a specific, completed action in the past ('la settimana scorsa'). 'Visitare' uses the auxiliary 'avere', resulting in 'ho visitato'.

complete_sentence: Mentre studiavo, è arrivato Mario.
question_text: Mentre ___, è arrivato Mario. (studiare)
english_translation: While I was studying, Mario arrived.
explanation: RULE: The 'imperfetto' is used to describe an ongoing action in the past that was interrupted by another event. The 'io' form of 'studiare' is 'studiavo'.

complete_sentence: L'anno prossimo andrò in Francia
question_text: L'anno prossimo ___ in Francia
english_translation: Next year I'll go to France.
explanation: RULE: 'Futuro semplice' is used for future plans. The first-person singular ('io') future form of the irregular verb 'andare' is 'andrò'.

complete_sentence: Domani sarà il compleanno di mio fratello
question_text: Domani ___ il compleanno di mio fratello
english_translation: Tomorrow is my brother's birthday.
explanation: RULE: 'Futuro semplice' is used to talk about future events. The third-person singular future form of 'essere' is 'sarà'.

complete_sentence: La settimana prossima comincerò il nuovo lavoro
question_text: La settimana prossima ___ il nuovo lavoro
english_translation: Next week I'll start the new job.
explanation: RULE: 'Futuro semplice' is used to describe future actions. The first-person singular ('io') future form of 'cominciare' is 'comincerò'.

complete_sentence: Quest'estate andremo in vacanza al mare
question_text: Quest'estate ___ in vacanza al mare
english_translation: This summer we'll go on vacation to the beach.
explanation: RULE: 'Futuro semplice' is used for future plans. The first-person plural ('noi') future form of 'andare' is 'andremo'.

complete_sentence: Tra due anni mi laureerò dall'università
question_text: Tra due anni ___ dall'università
english_translation: In two years I'll graduate from university.
explanation: RULE: This requires the 'futuro semplice' of the reflexive verb 'laurearsi'. The reflexive pronoun for 'io' is 'mi', and the future conjugation is 'laureerò', resulting in 'mi laureerò'.

complete_sentence: Io prenderei volentieri un caffè.
question_text: Io ___ volentieri un caffè. (prendere)
english_translation: I would gladly have a coffee.
explanation: RULE: The 'condizionale' is used to express a polite desire or wish. The first-person singular ('io') conditional form of 'prendere' is 'prenderei'.

complete_sentence: Noi vorremmo andare al cinema.
question_text: Noi ___ andare al cinema. (volere)
english_translation: We would like to go to the movies.
explanation: RULE: The 'condizionale' is used to express a wish. The first-person plural ('noi') conditional form of 'volere' is the irregular 'vorremmo'.

complete_sentence: Lei dovrebbe studiare di più.
question_text: Lei ___ studiare di più. (dovere)
english_translation: She should study more.
explanation: RULE: The 'condizionale' is used to give advice or make a suggestion. The third-person singular ('lei') conditional form of 'dovere' is 'dovrebbe'.

complete_sentence: Voi vorreste venire alla festa?
question_text: Voi ___ venire alla festa? (volere)
english_translation: Would you like to come to the party?
explanation: RULE: The 'condizionale' is used for polite invitations. The second-person plural ('voi') conditional form of 'volere' is the irregular 'vorreste'.

complete_sentence: Il ristorante è più caro del bar.
question_text: Il ristorante è ___ caro del bar.
english_translation: The restaurant is more expensive than the bar.
explanation: RULE: To form a comparative of superiority (more expensive), 'più' is used before the adjective.

complete_sentence: Maria studia più attentamente di Paolo.
question_text: Maria studia ___ attentamente di Paolo.
english_translation: Maria studies more carefully than Paolo.
explanation: RULE: To form a comparative of superiority with an adverb (more carefully), 'più' is used before the adverb.

complete_sentence: Luigi è tanto alto quanto Marco.
question_text: Luigi è ___ alto quanto Marco.
english_translation: Luigi is as tall as Marco.
explanation: RULE: To form a comparative of equality (as...as), the structure 'tanto...quanto' or 'così...come' is used. Here, 'tanto' completes the expression.

complete_sentence: È la più bella giornata dell'anno.
question_text: È la ___ bella giornata dell'anno.
english_translation: It's the most beautiful day of the year.
explanation: RULE: To form the relative superlative, the structure 'la + più + [adjective]' is used for a feminine noun like 'giornata'.

complete_sentence: Questo è il libro più noioso che abbia mai letto.
question_text: Questo è il libro ___ noioso che abbia mai letto.
english_translation: This is the most boring book I've ever read.
explanation: RULE: To express the highest degree of a quality (the most boring), the superlative structure 'il + più + [adjective]' is used.

complete_sentence: Questo è il momento più importante della giornata.
question_text: Questo è il momento ___ importante della giornata.
english_translation: This is the most important moment of the day.
explanation: RULE: The relative superlative for a masculine noun ('momento') is formed with 'il + più + [adjective]'.

complete_sentence: Sono sono le otto.
question_text: ___ sono le otto.
english_translation: It's eight o'clock.
explanation: RULE: To tell time for any hour other than one o'clock, the phrase 'Sono le...' is used, followed by the number.

complete_sentence: Vado a/a scuola ___ piedi.
question_text: Vado ___ scuola ___ piedi.
english_translation: I go to school on foot.
explanation: RULE: The expression 'to go to school' is 'andare a scuola', and the expression for 'on foot' is 'a piedi'. Both use the preposition 'a'.

complete_sentence: Di chi è libro questo?
question_text: ___ è libro questo?
english_translation: Whose book is this?
explanation: RULE: The interrogative phrase 'Di chi' is used to ask about possession, meaning 'Whose'.

complete_sentence: Quanto costa questo vestito?
question_text: ___ costa questo vestito?
english_translation: How much does this dress cost?
explanation: RULE: The interrogative word 'Quanto' is used to ask about price or quantity, meaning 'How much'.

complete_sentence: Quanti anni hai?
question_text: ___ anni hai?
english_translation: How old are you?
explanation: RULE: The interrogative phrase 'Quanti anni hai?' is the standard way to ask someone's age. 'Quanti' is used because 'anni' is a plural masculine noun.

complete_sentence: Dove vai in vacanza?
question_text: ___ vai in vacanza?
english_translation: Where are you going on vacation?
explanation: RULE: The interrogative word 'Dove' is used to ask about location, meaning 'Where'.

complete_sentence: Quale colore preferisci?
question_text: ___ colore preferisci?
english_translation: Which color do you prefer?
explanation: RULE: The interrogative word 'Quale' is used to ask for a choice between options, meaning 'Which'.

complete_sentence: Mi piace giocare a calcio.
question_text: Mi piace ___ calcio.
english_translation: I like to play soccer.
explanation: RULE: After the verb 'piacere', an infinitive is used to talk about an activity. The verb 'giocare' requires the preposition 'a' before a sport.

complete_sentence: Penso spesso ai miei genitori.
question_text: Penso spesso ___ miei genitori.
english_translation: I often think about my parents.
explanation: RULE: The verb 'pensare' requires the preposition 'a' when it means 'to think about'. This preposition combines with the masculine plural article 'i' to become 'ai'.

complete_sentence: A me piace la pizza, a te ti piace?
question_text: A me piace la pizza, a te ___ piace?
english_translation: I like pizza, do you like it?
explanation: RULE: The verb 'piacere' uses indirect object pronouns. To ask 'do you like it?' (referring to 'tu'), the pronoun 'ti' is used.

complete_sentence: Mi piacciono molto i gelati.
question_text: ___ piacciono molto i gelati.
english_translation: I like ice cream a lot.
explanation: RULE: The verb 'piacere' uses indirect object pronouns. The first-person singular pronoun is 'mi'. The verb form is 'piacciono' because the subject, 'i gelati', is plural.

complete_sentence: A lui non piace il caffè.
question_text: A lui non ___ il caffè.
english_translation: He doesn't like coffee.
explanation: RULE: The verb 'piacere' is used in its singular form, 'piace', because the subject, 'il caffè', is singular.

complete_sentence: Ho comprato alcuni libri interessanti.
question_text: Ho comprato ___ libri interessanti.
english_translation: I bought some interesting books.
explanation: RULE: The indefinite adjective 'alcuni' means 'some' or 'a few' and is used with plural nouns.

complete_sentence: Non ho nessun tempo oggi.
question_text: Non ho ___ tempo oggi.
english_translation: I don't have any time today.
explanation: RULE: In a negative sentence, 'nessuno' (which shortens to 'nessun' before a masculine noun) is used to mean 'no' or 'any'.

complete_sentence: Ogni studente deve studiare.
question_text: ___ studente deve studiare.
english_translation: Every student must study.
explanation: RULE: The indefinite adjective 'Ogni' means 'every' or 'each' and is always followed by a singular noun.

complete_sentence: Ho comprato qualche pane per cena.
question_text: Ho comprato ___ pane per cena.
english_translation: I bought some bread for dinner.
explanation: RULE: The indefinite adjective 'qualche' means 'some' and is always followed by a singular noun, even if the meaning is plural.

complete_sentence: Tutta la classe è andata in gita.
question_text: ___ la classe è andata in gita.
english_translation: The whole class went on a trip.
explanation: RULE: The indefinite adjective 'Tutto/a' means 'all' or 'the whole'. It must agree with the gender and number of the noun, so for 'la classe' it is 'Tutta'.

complete_sentence: La chiamiamo stasera
question_text: ___ chiamiamo stasera
english_translation: We'll call her tonight.
explanation: RULE: The direct object pronoun for a feminine singular object ('Maria') is 'La'.

complete_sentence: Li ho comprati ieri
question_text: ___ ho comprati ieri
english_translation: I bought them yesterday.
explanation: RULE: The direct object pronoun for a masculine plural object ('i libri') is 'Li'.

complete_sentence: Le vedo domani
question_text: ___ vedo domani
english_translation: I'll see them tomorrow.
explanation: RULE: The direct object pronoun for a feminine plural object ('le amiche') is 'Le'.

complete_sentence: Non la conosco
question_text: Non ___ conosco
english_translation: I don't know this person.
explanation: RULE: 'Questa persona' is a feminine singular noun, so the corresponding direct object pronoun is 'la'.

complete_sentence: Le ho scritto un'email
question_text: ___ ho scritto un'email
english_translation: I wrote her an email.
explanation: RULE: The indirect object pronoun for 'a Maria' (to her) is 'Le'.

complete_sentence: Gli ho parlato al telefono
question_text: ___ ho parlato al telefono
english_translation: I spoke to them on the phone.
explanation: RULE: The indirect object pronoun for 'a loro' or 'ai miei amici' (to them) is 'Gli' in modern common usage.

complete_sentence: Ci ha detto la verità
question_text: ___ ha detto la verità
english_translation: He told us the truth.
explanation: RULE: The indirect object pronoun that corresponds to 'a noi' (to us) is 'Ci'.

complete_sentence: Di libri ne ho molti.
question_text: Di libri ___ ho molti.
english_translation: I have many books.
explanation: RULE: The particle 'ne' is used to replace a quantity mentioned previously ('di libri'). It can be translated as 'of them'.

complete_sentence: Quanto pane vuoi? Ne voglio poco.
question_text: Quanto pane vuoi? ___ voglio poco.
english_translation: How much bread do you want? I want a little.
explanation: RULE: The particle 'ne' is used to mean 'of it' when referring to a part of something or a quantity of an uncountable noun like 'pane'.

complete_sentence: Hai parlato di politica? Sì, ne abbiamo parlato.
question_text: Hai parlato di politica? Sì, ___ abbiamo parlato.
english_translation: Did you talk about politics? Yes, we talked about it.
explanation: RULE: The particle 'ne' is used to replace the phrase 'di + [topic]', in this case 'di politica'. It can be translated as 'about it'.

complete_sentence: Hai bisogno di aiuto? No, non ne ho bisogno.
question_text: Hai bisogno di aiuto? No, non ___ ho bisogno.
english_translation: Do you need help? No, I don't need any.
explanation: RULE: The particle 'ne' is used to replace 'di + something' in expressions like 'avere bisogno di'. Here it replaces 'di aiuto'.

complete_sentence: Ieri mi sono alzato alle sette.
question_text: Ieri mi ___ alzato alle sette.
english_translation: Yesterday I got up at seven.
explanation: RULE: Reflexive verbs in the 'passato prossimo' always use the auxiliary verb 'essere'. The correct form for 'io' (mi) is 'sono'.

complete_sentence: Lei si è vestita velocemente.
question_text: Lei si ___ vestita velocemente.
english_translation: She got dressed quickly.
explanation: RULE: Reflexive verbs in the 'passato prossimo' always use the auxiliary verb 'essere'. The correct form for 'lei' (si) is 'è'.

complete_sentence: Noi ci siamo divertiti alla festa.
question_text: Noi ci ___ divertiti alla festa.
english_translation: We had fun at the party.
explanation: RULE: Reflexive verbs in the 'passato prossimo' always use the auxiliary verb 'essere'. The correct form for 'noi' (ci) is 'siamo'.

complete_sentence: Vi siete svegliati presto?
question_text: Vi ___ svegliati presto?
english_translation: Did you wake up early?
explanation: RULE: Reflexive verbs in the 'passato prossimo' always use the auxiliary verb 'essere'. The correct form for 'voi' (vi) is 'siete'.

complete_sentence: Loro si sono sposati l'anno scorso.
question_text: Loro si ___ sposati l'anno scorso.
english_translation: They got married last year.
explanation: RULE: Reflexive verbs in the 'passato prossimo' always use the auxiliary verb 'essere'. The correct form for 'loro' (si) is 'sono'.

complete_sentence: Stai attento in classe!
question_text: ___ attento in classe!
english_translation: Be careful in class!
explanation: RULE: The 'imperativo' is used to give commands. The informal second-person singular ('tu') form of the irregular verb 'stare' is 'Stai'.

complete_sentence: Venite qui!
question_text: ___ qui!
english_translation: Come here!
explanation: RULE: The 'imperativo' is used to give commands. The second-person plural ('voi') form of 'venire' is 'Venite'.

complete_sentence: Apri la finestra!
question_text: ___ la finestra!
english_translation: Open the window!
explanation: RULE: To give an informal command ('tu'), the 'imperativo' form for regular -ire verbs like 'aprire' is 'Apri'.

complete_sentence: Parlate piano!
question_text: ___ piano!
english_translation: Speak quietly!
explanation: RULE: To give a command to a group ('voi'), the 'imperativo' form for regular -are verbs like 'parlare' is 'Parlate'.

complete_sentence: Non essere nervoso!
question_text: Non ___ nervoso!
english_translation: Don't be nervous!
explanation: RULE: The negative informal imperative ('tu') is formed with 'non + infinitive'. Therefore, the correct form is 'non essere'.

complete_sentence: Non guidare troppo veloce!
question_text: Non ___ troppo veloce!
english_translation: Don't drive too fast!
explanation: RULE: To form the negative imperative for 'tu', the structure 'non + infinitive' is used. Thus, the correct form is 'non guidare'.

complete_sentence: Non fare rumore!
question_text: Non ___ rumore!
english_translation: Don't make noise!
explanation: RULE: To form the negative imperative use the infinitif, in this case 'fare'.

complete_sentence: Cosa stai facendo?
question_text: Cosa ___ facendo?
english_translation: What are you doing?
explanation: RULE: The progressive form, expressing an ongoing action, is made with the present tense of 'stare' + the gerund. For 'tu', this is 'stai facendo'.

complete_sentence: Sto studiando italiano.
question_text: ___ studiando italiano.
english_translation: I'm studying Italian.
explanation: RULE: To express an action happening right now, the structure 'stare + gerund' is used. The first-person singular ('io') form is 'Sto'.

complete_sentence: Loro stanno guardando la TV.
question_text: Loro ___ guardando la TV.
english_translation: They're watching TV.
explanation: RULE: The progressive form 'stare + gerund' is used for ongoing actions. The third-person plural ('loro') form is 'stanno'.

complete_sentence: Noi stiamo aspettando l'autobus.
question_text: Noi ___ aspettando l'autobus.
english_translation: We're waiting for the bus.
explanation: RULE: To express an action in progress, the structure 'stare + gerund' is used. The first-person plural ('noi') form is 'stiamo'.

complete_sentence: Sta per piovere.
question_text: ___ per piovere.
english_translation: It's about to rain.
explanation: RULE: To express an immediate future action, the phrase 'stare per + infinitive' is used. For weather, the third-person singular form is used: 'Sta per piovere'.

complete_sentence: Il treno sta per partire.
question_text: Il treno ___ per partire.
english_translation: The train is about to leave.
explanation: RULE: The expression 'stare per + infinitive' indicates that an action is imminent. For 'il treno', the correct form is 'sta per partire'.

complete_sentence: Io studio italiano ogni giorno.
question_text: Io ___ italiano ogni giorno.
english_translation: I study Italian every day.
explanation: RULE: The 'presente indicativo' is used for habitual actions. The first-person singular ('io') form of the -are verb 'studiare' is 'studio'.

complete_sentence: Tu abiti in una bella casa.
question_text: Tu ___ in una bella casa.
english_translation: You live in a beautiful house.
explanation: RULE: The 'presente indicativo' is used to state facts. The second-person singular ('tu') form of the -are verb 'abitare' is 'abiti'.

complete_sentence: Lei cucina molto bene.
question_text: Lei ___ molto bene.
english_translation: She cooks very well.
explanation: RULE: The 'presente indicativo' is used for regular activities. The third-person singular ('lei') form of the -are verb 'cucinare' is 'cucina'.

complete_sentence: Noi andiamo spesso al cinema.
question_text: Noi ___ spesso al cinema.
english_translation: We often go to the movies.
explanation: RULE: The 'presente indicativo' is used for habitual actions. The first-person plural ('noi') form of the irregular verb 'andare' is 'andiamo'.

complete_sentence: Voi arrivate sempre in ritardo.
question_text: Voi ___ sempre in ritardo.
english_translation: You're always late.
explanation: RULE: The 'presente indicativo' is used to describe habits. The second-person plural ('voi') form of the -are verb 'arrivare' is 'arrivate'.

complete_sentence: Da bambino mangiavo sempre la pizza.
question_text: Da bambino ___ sempre la pizza.
english_translation: As a child, I always ate pizza.
explanation: RULE: The 'imperfetto' is used to describe habitual actions in the past, especially in childhood. The 'io' form is 'mangiavo'.

complete_sentence: L'estate scorsa sono andato in Grecia
question_text: L'estate scorsa ___ in Grecia
english_translation: Last summer I went to Greece.
explanation: RULE: The 'passato prossimo' is used for a single, completed action in the past at a specific time ('l'estate scorsa'). 'Andare' uses 'essere', so the form is 'sono andato'.

complete_sentence: Quando ero piccolo, giocavo con i miei giocattoli.
question_text: Quando ero piccolo, ___ con i miei giocattoli.
english_translation: When I was little, I used to play with my toys.
explanation: RULE: The 'imperfetto' is used to describe repeated or habitual actions in the past ('used to play'). The 'io' form is 'giocavo'.

complete_sentence: Ieri ho dormito tutto il giorno perché ero malato.
question_text: Ieri ___ tutto il giorno perché ero malato.
english_translation: Yesterday I slept all day because I was sick.
explanation: RULE: The 'passato prossimo' is used for a completed action that occurred within a specific past time frame ('ieri'). 'Dormire' uses 'avere', so the form is 'ho dormito'.

complete_sentence: Mia nonna cucinava molto bene.
question_text: Mia nonna ___ molto bene.
english_translation: My grandmother cooked very well.
explanation: RULE: The 'imperfetto' is used to describe a general characteristic or ability of someone in the past. The 'lei' form is 'cucinava'.

complete_sentence: Quando avevo dieci anni, giocavo calcio ogni domenica.
question_text: Quando avevo dieci anni, ___ calcio ogni domenica.
english_translation: When I was 10, I played soccer every Sunday.
explanation: RULE: The 'imperfetto' is used to describe a regular, habitual activity in the past ('every Sunday'). The 'io' form is 'giocavo'.

complete_sentence: Nel duemiladiciannove ho trovato il mio primo lavoro.
question_text: Nel duemiladiciannove ___ il mio primo lavoro.
english_translation: In 2019 I found my first job.
explanation: RULE: The 'passato prossimo' is used for a specific, completed event in the past ('Nel 2019'). 'Trovare' uses 'avere', so the form is 'ho trovato'.

complete_sentence: Da studente studiavo sempre in biblioteca.
question_text: Da studente ___ sempre in biblioteca.
english_translation: As a student, I always studied in the library.
explanation: RULE: The 'imperfetto' is used to describe a habitual behavior in the past. The 'io' form is 'studiavo'.

complete_sentence: Quand'ero giovane facevo molto sport.
question_text: Quand'ero giovane ___ molto sport.
english_translation: When I was young, I did a lot of sports.
explanation: RULE: The 'imperfetto' is used to describe past habits and routines. The 'io' form of 'fare' is 'facevo'.

complete_sentence: L'anno scorso andavo in montagna ogni weekend.
question_text: L'anno scorso ___ in montagna ogni weekend.
english_translation: Last year I went to the mountains every weekend.
explanation: RULE: The 'imperfetto' is used to describe repeated actions in the past ('every weekend'). The 'io' form of 'andare' is 'andavo'.

complete_sentence: Marco è basso e ha i capelli biondi.
question_text: Marco è ___ e ha i capelli biondi.
english_translation: Marco is short and has blond hair.
explanation: RULE: For physical descriptions, the adjective must agree with the noun's gender and number. 'Marco' is masculine singular, so the correct adjective is 'basso'.

complete_sentence: La mia amica è molto gentile e amichevole.
question_text: La mia amica è molto ___ e amichevole.
english_translation: My friend is very kind and friendly.
explanation: RULE: For personality descriptions, the adjective must agree with the noun. 'Gentile' is an adjective that is the same for both masculine and feminine singular forms.

complete_sentence: Il mio professore ha i capelli grigi e gli occhi verdi.
question_text: Il mio professore ha ___ grigi e gli occhi verdi.
english_translation: My teacher has gray hair and green eyes.
explanation: RULE: The Italian word for 'hair' is 'i capelli', which is always used in the masculine plural form.

complete_sentence: Roma è una città molto grande e interessante.
question_text: Roma è una città molto ___ e interessante.
english_translation: Rome is a very big and interesting city.
explanation: RULE: To describe the size of 'una città' (a city), the adjective 'grande' (big/large) is appropriate.

complete_sentence: Il gatto è più piccolo del cane.
question_text: Il gatto è ___ del cane.
english_translation: The cat is smaller than the dog.
explanation: RULE: To make a size comparison (smaller than), the structure 'più piccolo di' is used.

complete_sentence: Questa strada è più tranquilla del centro. (more quiet")"
question_text: Questa strada è ___ del centro. (more quiet")"
english_translation: This street is quieter than downtown.
explanation: RULE: To compare a quality (quieter than), the structure 'più + [adjective] + di' is used. The adjective 'tranquilla' agrees with the feminine noun 'strada'.

complete_sentence: La mia casa ha tre camere da letto.
question_text: La mia casa ha ___ camere da letto.
english_translation: My house has three bedrooms.
explanation: RULE: To state a quantity, a cardinal number is used. The word for 'three' is 'tre'.

complete_sentence: Il mio appartamento è al secondo piano.
question_text: Il mio appartamento è al ___ piano.
english_translation: My apartment is on the second floor.
explanation: RULE: To indicate the floor of a building, an ordinal number is used. For the masculine noun 'piano', the correct form is 'secondo'.

complete_sentence: Mio fratello è più giovane di me.
question_text: Mio fratello è ___ di me.
english_translation: My brother is younger than me.
explanation: RULE: To make an age comparison (younger than), the phrase 'più giovane di' is used.

complete_sentence: Lei è una persona molto intelligente.
question_text: Lei è una persona molto ___.
english_translation: She is a very intelligent person.
explanation: RULE: 'Intelligente' is an adjective describing personality that is the same for both masculine and feminine singular forms.

complete_sentence: Mi fa male la testa.
question_text: Mi fa male ___.
english_translation: My head hurts.
explanation: RULE: The expression 'mi fa male' is followed by the body part. 'Head' is 'la testa', a feminine singular noun.

complete_sentence: Ho mal di gola.
question_text: Ho ___ di gola.
english_translation: I have a sore throat.
explanation: RULE: The fixed expression for 'sore throat' is 'mal di gola'.

complete_sentence: Prendo questa medicina per il raffreddore.
question_text: Prendo questa ___ per il raffreddore.
english_translation: I'm taking this medicine for my cold.
explanation: RULE: The Italian word for 'medicine' in a general sense is 'medicina'.

complete_sentence: Ho bisogno di riposare perché non dormo bene.
question_text: Ho bisogno di ___ perché non dormo bene.
english_translation: I need to rest because I don't sleep well.
explanation: RULE: The expression 'ho bisogno di' (I need) must be followed by an infinitive verb, in this case 'riposare' (to rest).

complete_sentence: Il medico mi ha detto di bere molta acqua.
question_text: Il medico mi ha detto di ___ molta acqua.
english_translation: The doctor told me to drink lots of water.
explanation: RULE: The expression 'dire di' (to tell to) must be followed by an infinitive verb, such as 'bere' (to drink).

complete_sentence: Non mi sento bene oggi.
question_text: Non mi sento ___ oggi.
english_translation: I don't feel well today.
explanation: RULE: The verb 'sentirsi' (to feel) is modified by an adverb. 'Bene' is the adverb meaning 'well', while 'buono' is an adjective.

complete_sentence: Ho mal allo stomaco.
question_text: Ho ___ allo stomaco.
english_translation: I have a stomachache.
explanation: RULE: The fixed expression for 'stomachache' is 'mal di stomaco'.

complete_sentence: Devo prendere una pillola.
question_text: Devo prendere una ___.
english_translation: I need to take a pill.
explanation: RULE: The word  'farmaco' can refer to any medicine or drug, which can be in pill form. 'Compresa' refers to a 'tablet'. 'Pillola' is correct here because it covers general types of pills.

complete_sentence: Ho la gamba rotta.
question_text: Ho la ___ rotta.
english_translation: I have a broken leg.
explanation: RULE: 'Gamba' is the Italian word for 'leg'. The adjective 'rotta' (broken) is feminine to agree with 'gamba'.

complete_sentence: Che taglia porta?
question_text: Che ___ porta?
english_translation: What size do you wear?
explanation: RULE: The question 'Che taglia?' is used to ask for a person's clothing size. Here 'porta' is for formal speech.

complete_sentence: Posso pagare con la carta?
question_text: Posso pagare ___?
english_translation: Can I pay by credit card?
explanation: RULE: The standard expression for 'to pay by card' is 'pagare con la carta'.

complete_sentence: È in offerta oggi?
question_text: È ___ oggi?
english_translation: Is it on sale today?
explanation: RULE: The fixed expression for something being 'on sale' or 'on special offer' is 'in offerta'.

complete_sentence: Posso provare questo vestito?
question_text: Posso ___ questo vestito?
english_translation: Can I try on this dress?
explanation: RULE: In the context of shopping, the verb 'provare' means 'to try on' clothes.

complete_sentence: Il negozio chiude alle diciannove.
question_text: Il negozio ___ alle diciannove.
english_translation: The store closes at 7 PM.
explanation: RULE: The verb 'chiudere' means 'to close'. The third-person singular present tense form is 'chiude'.

complete_sentence: Accettate carte di credito?
question_text: Accettate ___ di credito?
english_translation: Do you accept credit cards?
explanation: RULE: The plural form of 'credit card' ('carta di credito') is 'carte di credito'.

complete_sentence: Vorrei una taglia più piccola.
question_text: Vorrei ___ più piccola.
english_translation: I would like a smaller size.
explanation: RULE: When asking for a different clothing size, the word 'taglia' is used. 'Una taglia più piccola' means 'a smaller size'.

complete_sentence: Questo vestito mi sta bene.
question_text: Questo ___ mi sta bene.
english_translation: This dress fits me well.
explanation: RULE: The verb 'stare bene' means 'to fit well'. 'Vestito' is a masculine singular noun that fits the context.

complete_sentence: Dov'è il camerino?
question_text: Dov'è il ___?
english_translation: Where is the fitting room?
explanation: RULE: The Italian word for 'fitting room' is 'camerino'.

complete_sentence: Il menù, per favore.
question_text: Il menù, ___.
english_translation: The menu, please.
explanation: RULE: To make a polite request in a restaurant or elsewhere, 'per favore' (please) is commonly used.

complete_sentence: Cosa prende da bere?
question_text: Cosa prende ___?
english_translation: What would you like to drink?
explanation: RULE: The phrase 'da bere' means 'to drink' and is used to ask someone what they would like to drink.

complete_sentence: Vorrei la pasta di primo.
question_text: Vorrei ___ di primo.
english_translation: I would like pasta as a first course.
explanation: RULE: 'Pasta' is a feminine singular noun, so it takes the definite article 'la'.

complete_sentence: Siamo in quattro.
question_text: Siamo in ___.
english_translation: We are four people.
explanation: RULE: To state the number of people in a group, the expression 'siamo in + [number]' is used. 'Quattro' means 'four'.

complete_sentence: Un tavolo per due, per favore.
question_text: Un tavolo ___ due, per favore.
english_translation: A table for two, please.
explanation: RULE: When booking a table, the preposition 'per' is used to indicate the number of people, meaning 'for'.

complete_sentence: La pasta è molto buona.
question_text: La pasta è molto ___.
english_translation: The pasta is very good.
explanation: RULE: The adjective 'buono' must agree in gender and number with the noun it describes. 'Pasta' is feminine singular, so the correct form is 'buona'.

complete_sentence: Posso avere un bicchiere d'acqua?
question_text: Posso avere ___ d'acqua?
english_translation: Can I have a glass of water?
explanation: RULE: The phrase 'un bicchiere d'acqua' means 'a glass of water'.

complete_sentence: Com' è preparato il pesce?
question_text: Com' ___ preparato il pesce?
english_translation: How is the fish prepared?
explanation: RULE: To ask how a dish is prepared, one can ask 'Come è preparato...?' (How is...prepared?).

complete_sentence: Vorrei un bicchiere di vino rosso.
question_text: Vorrei un ___ di vino rosso.
english_translation: I'd like a glass of red wine.
explanation: RULE: When ordering a single serving of wine, 'un bicchiere' (a glass) is the correct term.

complete_sentence: Ci vediamo domani.
question_text: Ci vediamo ___.
english_translation: See you tomorrow.
explanation: RULE: 'Domani' is the adverb of time that means 'tomorrow'. 'Ci vediamo domani' is a common way to say 'See you tomorrow'.

complete_sentence: Che ne dici di andare al cinema?
question_text: Che ne dici di ___ al cinema?
english_translation: What do you think about going to the movies?
explanation: RULE: The suggestion phrase 'Che ne dici di...?' must be followed by a verb in the infinitive form, such as 'andare'.

complete_sentence: Ti va di mangiare una pizza?
question_text: Ti va di ___ una pizza?
english_translation: Do you feel like having a pizza?
explanation: RULE: The informal proposal 'Ti va di...?' is followed by a verb in the infinitive form, in this case 'mangiare'.

complete_sentence: A che ora ci incontriamo?
question_text: A che ora ___?
english_translation: What time shall we meet?
explanation: RULE: 'Incontrarsi' is a reciprocal verb meaning 'to meet each other'. The first-person plural ('noi') form is 'ci incontriamo'.

complete_sentence: Hai tempo sabato sera?
question_text: Hai ___ sabato sera?
english_translation: Are you free Saturday evening?
explanation: RULE: The expression 'avere tempo' means 'to have time' or 'to be free'.

complete_sentence: Facciamo così per le otto?
question_text: Facciamo ___ per le otto?
english_translation: Shall we say eight o'clock?
explanation: RULE: The phrase 'Facciamo così' is an idiomatic way to make a suggestion, meaning 'Let's do this' or 'How about...'

complete_sentence: Non posso, ho già un impegno.
question_text: Non posso, ho già ___ impegno.
english_translation: I can't, I already have a commitment.
explanation: RULE: The expression 'avere un impegno' means 'to have a commitment/an engagement'. 'Un' is the correct article for the masculine noun 'impegno'.

complete_sentence: Perché non andiamo insieme?
question_text: Perché non ___ insieme?
english_translation: Why don't we go together?
explanation: RULE: To make a suggestion, the structure 'perché non + [first-person plural verb]' is often used. 'Andiamo' is the 'noi' form of 'andare'.

complete_sentence: Che cosa fai stasera?
question_text: Che cosa ___ stasera?
english_translation: What are you doing tonight?
explanation: RULE: When asking one person ('tu') about their plans, the second-person singular form of the verb is used. For 'fare', this is 'fai'.

complete_sentence: Prendiamo un appuntamento per domani
question_text: ___ un appuntamento per domani
english_translation: Let's make an appointment for tomorrow.
explanation: RULE: The expression 'prendere un appuntamento' means 'to make an appointment'. The 'noi' imperative form is 'Prendiamo'.

complete_sentence: Mi alzo alle sette ogni mattina.
question_text: Mi alzo ___ sette ogni mattina.
english_translation: I get up at seven every morning.
explanation: RULE: To state the time of a daily routine, the preposition 'alle' is used before the hour.

complete_sentence: Faccio colazione alle otto.
question_text: Faccio ___ alle otto.
english_translation: I have breakfast at eight.
explanation: RULE: The expression for 'to have breakfast' is 'fare colazione'.

complete_sentence: Vado a letto tardi.
question_text: Vado a letto ___.
english_translation: I go to bed late.
explanation: RULE: 'Tardi' is the adverb that means 'late'.

complete_sentence: Mi lavo sempre i denti prima di dormire.
question_text: ___ sempre i denti prima di dormire.
english_translation: I always brush my teeth before sleeping.
explanation: RULE: 'Lavarsi i denti' (to brush one's teeth) is a reflexive verb. The first-person singular form is 'Mi lavo'.

complete_sentence: La mattina faccio sempre la doccia.
question_text: La mattina ___ sempre la doccia.
english_translation: In the morning I always take a shower.
explanation: RULE: The common expression for 'to take a shower' is 'fare la doccia'. The 'io' form is 'faccio'.

complete_sentence: Dopo cena guardo un po' la televisione.
question_text: Dopo cena ___ un po' la televisione.
english_translation: After dinner I watch TV a bit.
explanation: RULE: The verb 'guardare' means 'to watch', and is used for watching television.

complete_sentence: Il fine settimana dormo più tardi.
question_text: Il fine settimana ___ più tardi.
english_translation: On weekends I sleep later.
explanation: RULE: 'Dormire' means 'to sleep'. The first-person singular present tense is 'dormo'.

complete_sentence: Prima di uscire mi vesto sempre.
question_text: Prima di uscire ___ sempre.
english_translation: Before going out I always get dressed.
explanation: RULE: 'Vestirsi' (to get dressed) is a reflexive verb. The first-person singular present tense is 'mi vesto'.

complete_sentence: Pranzo alle tredici.
question_text: ___ alle tredici.
english_translation: I have lunch at 1 PM.
explanation: RULE: The verb 'pranzare' specifically means 'to have lunch'. The 'io' form is 'Pranzo'.

complete_sentence: La sera guardo sempre le notizie.
question_text: La sera ___ sempre le notizie.
english_translation: In the evening I always watch the news.
explanation: RULE: The verb 'guardare' (to watch) is appropriate for watching the news.

complete_sentence: Gioco a calcio ogni martedì.
question_text: Gioco ___ calcio ogni martedì.
english_translation: I play soccer every Tuesday.
explanation: RULE: The verb 'giocare' (to play) is followed by the preposition 'a' when referring to sports.

complete_sentence: Mi piace leggere libri gialli.
question_text: Mi piace ___ libri gialli.
english_translation: I like to read mystery books.
explanation: RULE: The expression 'mi piace' is followed by a verb in the infinitive form, such as 'leggere' (to read).

complete_sentence: Suono la chitarra da cinque anni.
question_text: Suono la ___ da cinque anni.
english_translation: I've been playing guitar for five years.
explanation: RULE: The expression 'suonare la chitarra' means 'to play the guitar'.

complete_sentence: Faccio yoga tre volte a settimana.
question_text: Faccio ___ tre volte a settimana.
english_translation: I do yoga three times a week.
explanation: RULE: The expression for 'to do yoga' is 'fare yoga'. Usually, no article is needed.

complete_sentence: Preferisco gli sport all'aria aperta.
question_text: Preferisco ___ sport all'aria aperta.
english_translation: I prefer outdoor sports.
explanation: RULE: The noun 'sport' is masculine. Since it starts with 's + consonant', its plural definite article is 'gli'.

complete_sentence: Nel tempo libero guardo film.
question_text: Nel tempo libero ___ film.
english_translation: In my free time I watch movies.
explanation: RULE: The verb 'guardare' means 'to watch' and is used for watching films.

complete_sentence: Vado in montagna ogni weekend.
question_text: Vado in ___ ogni weekend.
english_translation: I go to the mountains every weekend.
explanation: RULE: The common expression for 'to go to the mountains' is 'andare in montagna'.

complete_sentence: Il mio capo è molto comprensivo.
question_text: Il mio ___ è molto comprensivo.
english_translation: My boss is very understanding.
explanation: RULE: The Italian word for 'boss' is 'capo'.

complete_sentence: Oggi ho una riunione importante.
question_text: Oggi ho una ___ importante.
english_translation: Today I have an important meeting.
explanation: RULE: The Italian word for 'meeting' is 'riunione'.

complete_sentence: Lavoro per una ditta italiana.
question_text: Lavoro ___ una ditta italiana.
english_translation: I work for an Italian company.
explanation: RULE: The preposition 'per' is used to mean 'for' in the context of working for a company.

complete_sentence: I miei colleghi sono simpatici.
question_text: I miei ___ sono simpatici.
english_translation: My colleagues are nice.
explanation: RULE: 'Colleghi' is the masculine plural form of 'collega', meaning 'colleagues'.

complete_sentence: Finisco di lavorare alle diciotto.
question_text: Finisco di lavorare ___ diciotto.
english_translation: I finish work at 6 PM.
explanation: RULE: To state the time when an action occurs, the preposition 'alle' is used before the hour.

complete_sentence: Ho una pausa a mezzogiorno.
question_text: Ho una pausa ___ mezzogiorno.
english_translation: I have a break at noon.
explanation: RULE: The expression for 'at noon' is 'a mezzogiorno'.

complete_sentence: Prenoto una camera singola.
question_text: Prenoto una ___ singola.
english_translation: I book a single room.
explanation: RULE: In a hotel context, 'una camera singola' means 'a single room'.

complete_sentence: Il volo parte alle quattordici e trenta.
question_text: Il volo ___ alle quattordici e trenta.
english_translation: The flight departs at 2:30 PM.
explanation: RULE: The verb 'partire' means 'to depart' or 'to leave'. The third-person singular form is 'parte'.

complete_sentence: Vorrei un biglietto di andata e ritorno.
question_text: Vorrei un biglietto di ___ e ritorno.
english_translation: I would like a round-trip ticket.
explanation: RULE: The fixed expression for a 'round trip' ticket is 'andata e ritorno'.

complete_sentence: Dov'è il check-in, per favore?
question_text: Dov'è il check-in, ___?
english_translation: Where is the check-in, please?
explanation: RULE: To make a polite question, 'per favore' (please) is added at the end.

complete_sentence: La mia valigia è molto pesante.
question_text: La mia ___ è molto pesante.
english_translation: My suitcase is very heavy.
explanation: RULE: The Italian word for 'suitcase' is 'valigia'.

complete_sentence: L'aereo ha due ore di ritardo.
question_text: L'aereo ha due ore di ___.
english_translation: The plane has a two-hour delay.
explanation: RULE: The Italian word for 'delay' is 'ritardo'.

complete_sentence: A che ora è la colazione?
question_text: A che ora è la ___?
english_translation: What time is breakfast?
explanation: RULE: When staying at a hotel, 'la colazione' refers to breakfast.

complete_sentence: Studio medicina all'università.
question_text: Studio ___ all'università.
english_translation: I study medicine at university.
explanation: RULE: The expression for 'to study medicine' is 'studiare medicina'.

complete_sentence: Devo dare un esame domani.
question_text: Devo ___ un esame domani.
english_translation: I have to take an exam tomorrow.
explanation: RULE: The idiomatic expression for 'to take an exam' is 'dare un esame'.

complete_sentence: Ho preso un bel voto.
question_text: Ho preso un bel ___.
english_translation: I got a good grade.
explanation: RULE: In an academic context, 'voto' means 'grade' or 'mark'.

complete_sentence: Il professore è molto severo.
question_text: Il professore è molto ___.
english_translation: The professor is very strict.
explanation: RULE: The adjective 'severo' means 'strict' and agrees with the masculine noun 'professore'.

complete_sentence: Che tempo fa oggi?
question_text: Che tempo ___ oggi?
english_translation: What's the weather like today?
explanation: RULE: The standard question to ask about the weather is 'Che tempo fa?'.

complete_sentence: Oggi fa molto caldo.
question_text: Oggi ___ molto caldo.
english_translation: Today it's very hot.
explanation: RULE: To describe the temperature, the expression 'fare caldo' (to be hot) or 'fare freddo' (to be cold) is used. The third-person form is 'fa'.

complete_sentence: Ieri ha piovuto tutto il giorno.
question_text: Ieri ___ tutto il giorno.
english_translation: Yesterday it rained all day.
explanation: RULE: For a completed action of raining in the past, the 'passato prossimo' is used. Weather verbs like 'piovere' typically use 'avere', resulting in 'ha piovuto'.

complete_sentence: Domani farà bel tempo.
question_text: Domani ___ bel tempo.
english_translation: Tomorrow there will be nice weather.
explanation: RULE: To talk about the weather in the future, the future tense of 'fare' is used. 'Farà bel tempo' means 'the weather will be nice'.

complete_sentence: In inverno nevica spesso.
question_text: In inverno ___ spesso.
english_translation: In winter it often snows.
explanation: RULE: 'Nevicare' (to snow) is an impersonal verb, used in the third-person singular 'nevica'.

complete_sentence: C'è vento oggi.
question_text: C'è ___ oggi.
english_translation: It's windy today.
explanation: RULE: To say 'it's windy', the expression 'C'è vento' is used.

complete_sentence: Il cielo è nuvoloso.
question_text: Il cielo è ___.
english_translation: The sky is cloudy.
explanation: RULE: The adjective 'nuvoloso' means 'cloudy'.

complete_sentence: La temperatura è di quindici gradi.
question_text: La temperatura è di quindici ___.
english_translation: The temperature is 15 degrees.
explanation: RULE: To state the temperature, the word 'gradi' (degrees) is used.

complete_sentence: In estate fa molto caldo.
question_text: In estate fa ___ caldo.
english_translation: In summer it's very hot.
explanation: RULE: To intensify an adjective or weather expression, the adverb 'molto' (very) is used.

complete_sentence: Tu sei uscito con gli amici ieri sera
question_text: Tu ___ uscito con gli amici ieri sera
english_translation: You went out with friends last night.
explanation: RULE: 'Uscire' is a verb of motion that uses 'essere' in the 'passato prossimo'. The second-person singular ('tu') form is 'sei uscito'.

complete_sentence: I bambini hanno giocato tutto il pomeriggio.
question_text: I bambini ___ giocato tutto il pomeriggio. (giocare)
english_translation: The children played all afternoon.
explanation: RULE: The verb 'giocare' uses the auxiliary verb 'avere' in the 'passato prossimo'. For 'i bambini' (loro), the form is 'hanno giocato'.

complete_sentence: Mia sorella è nata nel millenovecentonovantacinque.
question_text: Mia sorella ___ nata nel millenovecentonovantacinque. (nascere)
english_translation: My sister was born in 1995.
explanation: RULE: The verb 'nascere' (to be born) uses the auxiliary verb 'essere' in the 'passato prossimo'. For 'mia sorella' (lei), the form is 'è nata'.

complete_sentence: Noi abbiamo camminato per due ore.
question_text: Noi ___ camminato per due ore. (camminare)
english_translation: We walked for two hours.
explanation: RULE: When 'camminare' (to walk) indicates a duration of the activity rather than a destination, it uses the auxiliary verb 'avere'. The 'noi' form is 'abbiamo camminato'.

complete_sentence: Voi siete tornati a casa tardi.
question_text: Voi ___ tornati a casa tardi. (tornare)
english_translation: You came home late.
explanation: RULE: 'Tornare' (to return) is a verb of motion that uses 'essere' in the 'passato prossimo'. The 'voi' form is 'siete tornati'.

complete_sentence: Lei ha scritto una bellissima poesia.
question_text: Lei ___ una bellissima poesia. (scrivere)
english_translation: She wrote a beautiful poem.
explanation: RULE: The transitive verb 'scrivere' uses 'avere' in the 'passato prossimo' and has an irregular past participle, 'scritto'. The 'lei' form is 'ha scritto'.

complete_sentence: Io ho vissuto in Germania per tre anni.
question_text: Io ___ vissuto in Germania per tre anni. (vivere)
english_translation: I lived in Germany for three years.
explanation: RULE: The verb 'vivere' (to live) uses the auxiliary 'avere' when it emphasizes the duration of the action. The 'io' form is 'ho vissuto'.

complete_sentence: Loro sono rimasti a casa tutto il giorno.
question_text: Loro ___ rimasti a casa tutto il giorno. (rimanere)
english_translation: They stayed home all day.
explanation: RULE: The verb 'rimanere' (to stay/remain) is a verb of state that uses 'essere' in the 'passato prossimo'. The 'loro' form is 'sono rimasti'.

complete_sentence: Mentre studiavo, il telefono squillava.
question_text: Mentre studiavo, il telefono ___. (squillare)
english_translation: While I was studying, the phone rang.
explanation: RULE: 'Passato prossimo' is used for a sudden, completed action that interrupts an ongoing background action. The ringing of the phone ('ha squillato') interrupted the studying.

complete_sentence: Da piccola, Maria portava sempre la bambola.
question_text: Da piccola, Maria ___ sempre la bambola. (portare)
english_translation: As a little girl, Maria always carried her doll.
explanation: RULE: The 'imperfetto' is used to describe habitual or repeated actions in the past, especially in childhood. The 'lei' form is 'portava'.

complete_sentence: Ieri alle quindici camminavo al parco
question_text: Ieri alle quindici ___ al parco
english_translation: Yesterday at 3 PM I was walking in the park.
explanation: RULE: The 'imperfetto' is used to describe an action that was in progress at a specific point in time in the past. The 'io' form is 'camminavo'.

complete_sentence: L'anno scorso abbiamo visitato l'Italia per la prima volta
question_text: L'anno scorso ___ l'Italia per la prima volta
english_translation: Last year we visited Italy for the first time.
explanation: RULE: The 'passato prossimo' is used for a specific, completed action in the past ('l'anno scorso'). The 'noi' form is 'abbiamo visitato'.

complete_sentence: Alle otto di mattina ieri dormivano ancora
question_text: Alle otto di mattina ieri ___ ancora
english_translation: At 8 AM yesterday they were still sleeping.
explanation: RULE: The 'imperfetto' is used to describe an action that was in progress at a specific time in the past. The 'loro' form is 'dormivano'.

complete_sentence: Domani sera ceneremo al ristorante
question_text: Domani sera ___ al ristorante
english_translation: Tomorrow evening we will have dinner at the restaurant.
explanation: RULE: To talk about a future plan, the 'futuro semplice' is used. The 'noi' form for the -are verb 'cenare' is 'ceneremo'.

complete_sentence: La prossima settimana cercherò un nuovo lavoro
question_text: La prossima settimana ___ un nuovo lavoro
english_translation: Next week I will look for a new job.
explanation: RULE: The 'futuro semplice' is used to express a future action or intention. The 'io' form for 'cercare' is 'cercherò'.

complete_sentence: Tra un mese voi finirete gli esami
question_text: Tra un mese voi ___ gli esami
english_translation: In a month you will finish your exams.
explanation: RULE: To describe an action that will be completed in the future, the 'futuro semplice' is used. The 'voi' form for the -ire verb 'finire' is 'finirete'.

complete_sentence: Stasera lui tornerà tardi dal lavoro
question_text: Stasera lui ___ tardi dal lavoro
english_translation: Tonight he will come home late from work.
